Co possesses outstanding dehydrogenation and hydrogenation activitiy and is a suitable catalyst for the amination of ethylene glycol. Nevertheless, the catalytic activity of Co's different crystal surfaces remains unclear, which hinders the further advancements in its catalytic efficiency. This research comprehensively examines the influence of Co's crystal plane effect on the amination of ethylene glycol employing both experimental and theoretical methodologies. Three single-crystal Co catalysts with mainly exposed (10−11), (0001) and (11−20) crystal planes were synthesized by a hydrothermal method and evaluated for ethylene glycol amination. The experimental results indicated that the c-Co-R catalyst with exposed Co (11–20) crystal facets exhibits optimal performance, with a 55.4 % ethylene glycol conversion and a 43.7 % primary amines (ethylenediamine and ethanolamine) selectivity. Combined with density-functional theory calculations and experimental characterization, the results showed that the Co (11−20) surface exhibited robust C-H bond dissociation and strong adsorption of ethylene glycol, which markedly improved the dehydrogenation efficiency of ethylene glycol and improved ethylene glycol conversion. Furthermore, the weak adsorption capacity of NH3 further promoted the selectivity of the target products. Graphical abstract Image, graphical abstract Keywords Crystal plane of Co Cobalt-based catalyst Ethylene glycol amination Ethylenediamine Ethanolamine Data availability Data will be made available on request. 1 Introduction As significant chemical intermediates, ethylenediamine (EDA) and ethanolamine (MEA) are extensively employed in the production of chelating agents, polyamide resins, surfactants, and pharmaceutical intermediates [1,2]. Currently, the industrial production of MEA and EDA primarily relies on the ethylene oxide and dichloroethane methods, which encounter numerous challenges, including safety risks, substantial emissions of waste [3], and susceptibility to regulatory constraints imposed by the petroleum sector. The direct amination of coal-based ethylene glycol (EG) to MEA and EDA has attracted much more attention as a more direct and environmentally friendly method [4,5]. The key to the direct amination of EG lies in catalyst design. During the alcohol amination process, alcohols are firstly dehydrogenated to form aldehydes, and then aldehydes are combined with NH3 to form imines, finally, the imines are hydrogenated to form the requisite amine products [6–8]. Among these steps, the rate-determining step is the alcohol's C-H bond breaking [9–14], requiring a catalyst with optimal dehydrogenation capability. It has been demonstrated that precious metal catalysts, such as Ru [15–18]and Ir [19–21], exhibit remarkable efficacy in the amination of alcohols, but they are subject to specific constraints, including the high cost of ligand preparation and susceptibility to toxicity and deactivation. Ni and Co, as non-precious metals, exhibited excellent dehydrogenation and hydrogenation activity with cost-effective and abundant supply. Consequently, they are considered as promising catalysts for alcohol amination [11,22–25]. Compared with Ni, Co showed better EG amination performance because of the better dehydrogenation ability of EG in Co [26]. Nevertheless, the structure of metallic Co is complex, and the crystal plane effect is a significant factor influencing the catalytic performance of Co-based catalysts. Li and Zhang et al. synthesized Co3O4 with different crystal planes and found that Co3O4 with high-index facets exhibited robust C-H bond dissociation ability. Consequently, Co3O4 with high-index facets demonstrated exceptional activity in methane catalytic combustion reactions [27,28]. Li et al. reported that Co3O4 with exposed (110) facets had a stronger ethanol adsorption capacity, which enhanced performance [29]. Meng et al. reported that Co3O4 nanorods, which predominantly expose (110) crystal facets, could adsorb a significant amount of NH3, thereby enhancing NH3-SCR reaction activity [30]. In EG amination, the reactants' adsorption capacity and the ability to break C-H bonds are crucial for amination activity. In summary, the crystal plane effect of Co may influence C-H bond dissociation as well as the adsorption capacity of reactants, thereby affecting performance. However, the structure-property relationship between the crystal plane of Co and the performance of EG amination has not been established theoretically and experimentally, which hinders the rational design of efficient catalysts for EG amination. Therefore, rational regulation of the crystalline plane of Co is expected to regulate the activity of C-H bond dissociation and the adsorption capacity of reactants, thus improving the catalytic activity of the reaction. Therefore, this study focuses on hexagonal close-packed (HCP) Co with superior C-H bond dissociation capability. Three types of HCP Co with mainly exposed (10−11), (0001) and (11−20) crystal planes were synthesized and applied in EG amination. The effects of factors such as additives [31,32], supports [33,34], and particle size [35] on the reaction were excluded. Experimental characterization methods such as TEM, HR-TEM, ED, BET, H2-TPD, H2-TPR, NH3-TPD, in-situ Raman spectroscopy, XRD, EtOH-TPSR and XPS, along with Density Functional Theory (DFT) calculations were used to examine how Co's crystal plane effect influences EG conversion, primary amines selectivity and product distribution, which provided both theoretical and experimental basis for the rational design of highly active and selective Co-based catalysts for EG amination. 2 Experimental 2.1 Synthesis of catalysts 20 mL of anhydrous ethanol was evenly mixed with distilled water, then 4.8 g of Co(NO3)2·6H2O and 4 g of polyvinylpyrrolidone (PVP) were added. The liquid mixture was stirred for 0.5 h. A 0.1 L solution of NaOH (0.4 M) was added dropwise while stirring continued for an additional 30 min. The resulting solution was transferred into a polytetrafluoroethylene liner, sealed in a 200 mL autoclave, and the reaction was allowed to proceed at 120 °C for 10 h. Once the reaction was finished, the autoclave was permitted to cool naturally. The precipitate was centrifuged and washed three times. Following a 12 h drying period at 60 °C, the precipitate was subjected to calcination for a period of 5 h at a rate of 1 °C per minute at 500 °C. The resulting Co3O4 catalyst was designated as p-Co. To 114 mL of distilled water, 0.75 g of Co(CH3COO)2·4H2O and 2.4 g of polyvinylpyrrolidone (PVP) were added. The liquid mixture was stirred for 0.5 hour. Subsequently, the mixture was stirred for an additional 20 min following the addition of 1 M aqueous NaOH (6 mL). After stirring, the solution was transferred into a polytetrafluoroethylene liner, sealed in a 200 mL autoclave, and the reaction was conducted at 180 °C for 24 h. Following the completion of the reaction, the autoclave was permitted to cool naturally. Centrifugation was used to gather the precipitate, which was then three times cleaned. The precipitate was first dried for 12 h at 60 °C, and then it was calcined for 5 h at 500 °C, heating at a rate of 1 °C per minute, in a muffle furnace. The obtained Co3O4 catalyst was designated as s-Co. After mixing 60 mL of anhydrous ethanol with 40 mL of distilled water, 2 g of Co(CH3COO)2·4H2O was added, and the liquid mixture was stirred for 20 min. Following the addition of 10 mL of a 25 % ammonia solution, the mixture was stirred for a further 20 min. Once the solution had completed the stirring process, it was transferred into a polytetrafluoroethylene liner, sealed within a 200 mL autoclave, and permitted to react for a period of 3 h at a temperature of 170 °C. The autoclave was permitted to cool naturally once the reaction was finished. Centrifugation was used to gather the precipitate, which was then cleaned three times before being dried for 12 h at 60 °C. The Co3O4 catalyst that was obtained was called c-Co. Different morphologies of Co3O4 catalysts underwent a reduction and passivation process. First, the catalysts were placed in a tube furnace, and a 5 vol. % H2/N2 gas mixture was introduced. At a rate of 1 °C per minute, the temperature was increased to 400 °C and held there for six h. Following the reduction, the catalysts were passivated for 2 h at room temperature with a gas mixture of 0.5 vol. % O2/N2. Corresponding to p-Co, s-Co, and c-Co, respectively, the catalysts obtained through this treatment were named p-Co-R, s-Co-R, and c-Co-R [36]. 2.2 Catalyst performance evaluation The catalytic amination of EG was carried out in a 50 mL high-pressure autoclave. The autoclave was charged with 0.056 g catalyst, 0.56 g EG, 3 g water, and 5 g liquid ammonia. Following the purging of the system with hydrogen, the introduction of further hydrogen serves to elevate the pressure to 3 MPa. The reaction was then carried out at 185 °C for 12 h with stirring. After the reaction was complete, gas chromatography was used to quantify the end products. EG amination products were subjected to a qualitative examination utilizing a Shimadzu QP2010 Plus gas chromatography-mass spectrometry (GCMS–) instrument. Helium was used as the carrier gas. The temperature of the injector and detector was kept constant at 250 °C. The components of the reaction mixture were separated using an Rtx-Wax capillary column with programmed temperature control: After 2 min at 80 °C, the temperature was ramped up to 110 °C at a rate of 15 °C per minute, and then to 220 °C at a rate of 35 °C per minute, where it remained for 10 min. The temperature of the evaporator was kept constant at 250 °C, and the flame ionization detector (FID) temperature was also set at the same temperature. The FID's carrier gas was nitrogen (N2), which was utilized at a flow rate of 30 mL/min. Using an internal standard method, a quantitative analysis of the products was carried out. A certain amount of n-propanol was added as an internal standard, and an appropriate amount of anhydrous ethanol was used as a co-solvent. The conversion of EG, selectivity (S), and yield (Y) of the products were calculated as follows: CONV ERSIO N EG = n EG 0 − n EG n EG 0 × 100 % S = n i n EG 0 − n EG × 100 % Y = n i n EG 0 × 100 % Within this specific scenario, the variable n E G 0 and n E G are utilized to represent the initial EG and final EG in the autoclave, respectively; n i denotes the molar quantity of product i in the autoclave. 2.3 Catalyst characterization See Supporting Information for catalyst characterization details. 2.4 Calculation details See Supporting Information for Calculation details. 3 Results and discussion 3.1 Catalytic performance of catalysts The performance of catalysts in the EG amination is summarized in Table 1 . At 185 °C, the EG conversion of p-Co-R, s-Co-R, and c-Co-R catalysts was 51.1 %, 35.0 %, and 55.4 %, while the selectivities towards the target products were 35.6 %, 19.8 %, and 43.7 %, respectively. Additionally, experiments varying the reaction temperature for the c-Co-R catalyst were conducted, and the results were presented in Table 1. As the temperature from 175 °C to 195 °C, EG conversion increased from 29.3 % to 57.2 %. However, primary amines (ethylenediamine and ethanolamine) selectivity initially increased and then decreased, with a similar trend observed for EDA selectivity, which reached the maximum at 185 °C. This phenomenon may be attributed to the decrease solubility of NH3 in the liquid phase at higher temperature, which promotes the sequential reaction of primary amines to by-products such as piperazines [37]. The c-Co-R catalyst exhibited the highest EG conversion and primary amines selectivity. The EG conversion was 55.4 %, the primary amines selectivity was 43.7 %, and the primary amines yield was 24.2 % at 185 °C. Furthermore, the yield of primary amines of c-Co-R was 6 % higher than that of p-Co-R and 17.3 % higher than that of s-Co-R. Thus, the c-Co-R catalyst proves to be more suitable for the amination of EG. These results highlight significant differences in the catalytic activity of the three Co-based catalysts in the EG amination. To further elucidate the reasons leading to different activities of the three Co catalysts, their physicochemical properties were characterized using a combined theoretical and experimental approach. 3.2 Characterization of catalysts Transmission Electron Microscopy (TEM) and High-Resolution Transmission Electron Microscopy (HR-TEM) were employed to characterize the morphology, size, and exposed crystal planes of the three Co catalysts. The Co nanoparticles (Fig. 1 a1, b1, c1, a2, b2, c2) derived from the corresponding Co3O4 nanoparticles (Fig. S1 a1, b1, c1, a2, b2, c2) maintain a consistent morphology after reduction and passivation. Electron diffraction patterns (ED, Fig. 1 a3, b3, c3) indicate that twinning or stacking faults are absent, confirming that all three Co nanoparticles exhibit single-crystal structures. Combined analysis of ED, HR-TEM, and Fast Fourier Transform (FFT, Fig. 1 a3, a4) reveals that p-Co-R has two crystal planes with an interfacial angle of 50°, associated with lattice distance of 0.19 nm and 0.15 nm, which are attributed to the (10−11) and (10–12) facets, respectively. This confirmed that major exposed facets of p-Co-R are (10−11). Additionally, s-Co-R (Fig. 1 b3, b4) exhibits lattice distance of 0.21 nm and an angle of 60° between the (10–10) and (01–10) planes, indicating that the main exposed facets are Co (0001). c-Co-R (Fig. 1 c3, c4) shows lattice distance of 0.20 nm and 0.15 nm, corresponding to the (0002) and (10–12) planes, respectively, with an angle of 43° between them. This result suggested that the major exposed planes of c-Co-R are (11−20). The specific surface areas of p-Co-R, s-Co-R and c-Co-R are 16.9, 13.2 and 30.0 m2 g–1. Based on this, it is confirmed that three pure-phase Co catalysts with similar sizes and morphologies but differing main exposed crystal planes have been successfully synthesized. The p-Co-R and s-Co-R catalysts exhibited uniform hexagonal nanosheets with a thickness of approximately 20–30 nm, while the c-Co-R catalyst displayed uniform nanocubes with an edge length of about 20 nm. s-Co-R and p-Co-R exclude the effect of morphology on EG amination due to their similarity. Additionally, catalytic performance can be affected when Co nanoparticles are smaller than 8–10 nm. The influence of particle size on catalytic performance can be ruled out because the particle diameters of all three catalysts exceeding 15 nm [38,39]. To further ascertain the structural information of the synthesized catalysts, X-ray powder diffraction (XRD) characterization was performed. After reduction and passivation, as shown in Fig. 2 a, novel diffraction peaks were observed at 41.6°, 44.5°, 47.5°, and 75.3° for the Co catalysts with different crystal planes, compared to the XRD patterns of Co3O4 nanoparticles with different morphologies (Fig. S2). These peaks correspond to the positions of the HCP Co (PDF#05–0727), proving that p-Co-R, s-Co-R, and c-Co-R were fully transformed from the original Co3O4 to HCP Co. The reduction behavior of Co3O4 with different morphologies was investigated by H₂-TPR (temperature-programmed reduction) technique, as shown in Fig. 2b. The three catalysts exhibit two distinct reduction peaks separately at 250–350 °C and 350–500 °C, corresponding to the reduction processes of Co3O4 to CoO and CoO to Co, respectively [40]. Additionally, the reduction temperature and peak shapes and peak positions of the three catalysts are very similar, which allows for the exclusion of reduction extent on EG amination. To further confirm the state of the synthesized Co catalysts, Raman spectroscopy was employed for characterization. Fig. s3 shows the in-situ Raman spectra of the catalysts. The catalyst was first reduced at 400 °C for 2h and then subjected to in situ Raman testing. None of the three Co catalysts with different crystal planes exhibit any Raman peaks, as the Co-O bonds disappeared after Co3O4 reduced to metallic Co. This result indicates that the main bulk phase of the catalyst after reduction passivation is Co. The H₂-TPD (temperature-programmed desorption) technique was employed to examine the hydrogen adsorption and desorption capabilities of the catalysts, with the results shown in Fig. s4. The almost absence of hydrogen desorption peaks of the three catalysts proves that the three catalysts with different crystal planes have the same hydrogen adsorption capacity, and the crystal plane effect of Co does not affect the H2 adsorption capacity, thereby exerting no impact on EG amination. Temperature-programmed surface reaction is a useful technique to identify the intermediates adsorbed on the catalyst and to elucidate the reaction mechanism. Ethanol (EtOH) was used as a probe to further elucidate the dehydrogenation reaction mechanism on different crystal planes of Co. EtOH-TPSR were performed on p-Co-R, c-Co-R, and s-Co-R. After EtOH adsorption, no desorption peaks for EtOH (M/Z=45, 31, 29) were detected on the three catalysts, but a desorption peak for acetaldehyde (M/Z=43) was observed in the 300–400 °C range, with the results displayed in Fig. 3 . EtOH readily adsorbs and dissociates on the Co surface, forming acetaldehyde via dehydrogenation [41–43]. Table 2 lists the integrated peak areas for the three different Co crystal planes. When the total desorption area of c-Co-R is normalized to 1, the values for p-Co-R and s-Co-R are 0.67 and 0.56, respectively. The order of acetaldehyde desorption peak area follows s-Co-R < p-Co-R < c-Co-R. This confirms that alcohols are more readily dehydrogenate on c-Co-R with exposed (11−20) planes. To investigate the effect of different Co's crystal facets on the reaction to form primary amines, NH3-TPD experiments were conducted on different Co crystal planes. When the total desorption area of c-Co-R is normalized to 1, the values for p-Co-R and s-Co-R are 2.96 and 1.78, respectively. All three catalysts showed two NH3 desorption peaks at 200–300 °C and 400–500 °C, as shown in Fig. 4 . Table 3 lists the integrated peak areas for the catalysts. Catalysts with exposed different crystal facets exhibit different NH3 desorption peak areas following the order c-Co-R < s-Co-R < p-Co-R, indicating that the adsorption capacity for NH3 followed the order of Co (11−20) < Co (0001) < Co (10−11). 3.3 DFT calculations for single-crystal Co catalysts with different crystal planes To clarify the effect of different Co crystalline surfaces on the amination of EG, detailed DFT calculations of C-H bond dissociation activation energies were conducted on the Co (10−11), Co (0001), and Co (11−20) facets, simulating the p-Co-R, s-Co-R, and c-Co-R catalysts, respectively. Previous studies concluded the speculation that alcohol dehydrogenation is the rate-determining step in reductive amination. According to the established EG dehydrogenation mechanism, the structures of the initial state (IS), transition state (TS), and final state (FS) for the key steps are shown in Fig. 5 . On the Co catalyst, the hydroxyl proton (H) of the EG molecule was first removed, followed by breaking of the α-H bond. The energy barriers for the breaking of the O-H and α-H bonds were further calculated, and the corresponding potential energy surface is presented in Fig. 6 . On the Co (0001), Co (10−11), and Co (11−20) crystal planes, the activation energies for C-H bond dissociation are 0.88 eV, 0.85 eV, and 0.76 eV, respectively, while those for O-H bond dissociation are 0.76 eV, 0.80 eV, and 0.70 eV, respectively. This shows that, on Co catalysts, the O-H bond in EG dissociates more easily than the C-H bond. Furthermore, the activation energies order for C-H bond dissociation is Co (11−20) < Co (10−11) < Co (0001), while for O-H bond dissociation, the order is Co (11−20) < Co (0001) < Co (10−11). The energy barriers for these steps on different Co crystal planes provided insights into the reaction pathway and rate-determining steps. By comparing the activation energies for O-H and C-H bond dissociation, the influence of the crystal plane on the dehydrogenation efficiency of EG can be clearly understood. Therefore, the Co (11−20) surface can be predicted to be the most active facet compared to the other two facets, which validates the EtOH-TPSR inference. Detailed DFT calculations of the adsorption capacity of EG were performed on Co (0001), Co (10−11), and Co (11−20) crystal planes. The different adsorption sites and possible configurations of EG on the Co crystal surfaces were studied (Fig. 7 ). EG binds to the top site via one O atom, with adsorption energies of −0.47 eV on Co (0001) and −0.64 eV on Co (10−11). EG can bind to the surface via two O atoms at two adjacent top sites with an adsorption energy of −0.70 eV on the Co (11−20) surface (Fig. 8 ). The adsorption ability of EG on different Co crystal planes follows the order: Co (0001) < Co (10−11) < Co (11−20). By comparing the adsorption abilities of EG on different Co crystal planes, it is evident that EG exhibits the highest adsorption strength on Co (11−20) plane. The adsorption energies of NH3 on the planes of the three different crystal plane Co catalysts were calculated. The most stable adsorption sites for NH3 in the Co (0001), Co (10−11) and Co (11−20) planes are the top sites (Fig. 9 ). The adsorption energy of NH₃ on the Co (11−20) plane of c-Co-R is −0.53 eV, on the Co (10−11) plane of p-Co-R is −0.69 eV, and on the Co (0001) plane of s-Co-R is −0.60 eV (Fig. 10 ). Thus, the order of NH₃ adsorption ability is Co (11−20) < Co (0001) < Co (10−11), which is consistent with the NH3-TPD. This indicates that the adsorption of NH₃ on Co (11−20) plane is weaker, leading to a shorter surface residence time and easier desorption. To provide insight into the difference in the adsorption strength, the projected density of state analysis about three Co crystal planes were further investigated. As shown in Fig. 11 , the spin-up and down states near the Fermi level are asymmetric for the considered surfaces, indicating that all Co facets have magnetic character. The downward shift of ε d on Co (10−11) surface empties more antibonding states, which could accept more electrons from NH3 and EG orbitals than that on Co (0001) and Co (11−20). However, since EG can bind to the Co (11−20) surface through two O atoms at two adjacent top sites, it is possible to adsorb a greater quantity of EG on the Co (11−20) crystal plane. This trend fits well with adsorption strength. Theoretical calculations reveal that the crystal plane effect of Co not only influences the bond-breaking capabilities of O-H and C-H bond but also affects the adsorption abilities of the reactants, EG and NH3. Therefore, from combined experimental and computational findings, the effects of the Co crystal plane on EG conversion, primary amines selectivity, and product distribution in EG amination were discussed. 3.4 Exploration of the structure-property relationship between the Co's crystal plane effect and catalytic performance 3.4.1 The effect of different Co crystal planes on EG conversion According to DFT calculations, the c-Co-R with exposed (11−20) crystal plane exhibited the strongest ability for C-H bond dissociation of EG. EtOH-TPSR also proved its excellent dehydrogenation performance. These lead to a higher concentration of intermediates from EG dehydrogenation, contributing to higher EG conversion. Plotting the dissociation energies of C-H bond and EG conversion (Fig. 12 a), it can be seen that a positive relationship was obtained between ability for C-H bond dissociation and EG conversion. Additionally, the relationship between the intensity of the aldehyde desorption peaks of the reaction intermediates and the EG conversion was further investigated (Fig. 12b), which demonstrated that excellent dehydrogenation performance is the key to improve EG conversion. Furthermore, EG conversion was plotted with ability of EG adsorption(Fig. 12c), It can be seen that stronger alcohol adsorption on Co catalysts enhanced EG dehydrogenation thereby increasing the reaction conversion [44]. Additionally, the NH3 adsorption on the catalyst surface can obscure active sites of Co, affecting Co's ability to adsorb alcohols and thereby reducing EG conversion [22]. Therefore, the results demonstrate a positive correlation between the dissociation ability of the C-H bond and reaction conversion. Similarly, the EG adsorption ability is also positively correlated with the reaction conversion. These findings elucidate that the c-Co-R catalysts with exposed Co (11−20) crystal plane exhibit elevated catalytic activity, which is attributed to the robust C-H dissociation capability and EG adsorption capacity. Based on the theoretical calculations and experimental characterization results, it can be concluded that the crystal plane effect of Co influences the ability to dissociate C-H bond, affecting the rate-determining step of EG amination and consequently impacting catalytic activity. Additionally, the adsorption strength of EG varies on the different crystal planes of the catalysts, leading to differences in their ability to promote EG dehydrogenation. This variation affects the activity of EG amination, which is a major factor contributing to the differences in conversion rates among the three catalysts. 3.4.2 The effect of different Co crystal planes on primary amines selectivity To investigate the relationship between primary amines selectivity and the crystal plane effect of Co, primary amines selectivity and NH3 adsorption were plotted as shown in Fig. 13 a, 13b. In this reaction, dehydrogenation to aldehydes on the Co surface is rate-determining step. The formed C=O bond is converted to a C=N bond through a nucleophilic attack by NH3, which is then hydrogenated to produce primary amines. The Co (10−11) and Co (0001) surfaces show stronger adsorption capacity for NH3. The strong adsorption on the Co surface makes NH₃ stabilizes the imine on the Co surface through hydrogen bonding, hindering the hydrogenation step [45,46]. Thus c-Co-R with exposed (11−20) facets has a higher primary amines selectivity than s-Co-R with exposed (0001) facets and p-Co-R with exposed (10−11) facets due to its weak NH3 adsorption capacity. Since the p-Co-R (10−11) plane is easier to dehydrogenate to produce intermediates, more intermediates can produce more primary amines. Therefore, the order of primary amines selectivity follows Co (0001) < Co (10−11) < Co (11−20). The results of theoretical calculations and experimental characterization indicate that NH3 adsorption on different crystal surfaces of the catalysts varies in strength, thus affecting the ability of amination hydrogenation to form primary amines. 3.4.3 By-product distribution in EG amination over Co catalysts with different crystal planes To identify the unknown by-products of EG amination which different crystal planes of Co catalyzed, GC–MS was used for qualitative analysis of the reaction product. The main by-product was determined, as shown in Scheme 1 . Besides the reactant EG and the target product EDA and MEA, the major components include ethanolamine, piperazine, hydroxyethylpiperazine, and aminoethylpiperazine. Based on the GC–MS results, the scheme of EG amination is proposed: EG is first dehydrogenated over Co catalysts to produce 2-hydroxyacetaldehyde (1), which then reacts with NH3 to form intermediate compounds that subsequently undergo hydrogenation to synthesize MEA (2). MEA, through steps including hydroxy dehydrogenation, amination, and hydrogenation, eventually forms EDA (3). EG also undergoes dehydration and condensation to produce a cyclic ether structure, which then undergoes ring-opening to form diglycol (4). MEA, EG, and EDA can participate in dehydrogenation, aldehyde-amine condensation reactions, and hydrogenation to yield by-products such as piperazine (7) and (8). Fischer et al. [47] proposed that in the reaction of EG with dimethylamine, the mechanism involves the dehydrogenation of EG to form 2-hydroxyacetaldehyde, which then reacts with dimethylamine to form N, N-dimethylethanolamine. Similarly, in this study, it is proposed that the intermediate 2-hydroxyacetaldehyde in the EG amination can react with piperazine to form hydroxyethylpiperazine (5). MEA dehydrogenates to form 2-aminoacetaldehyde, which reacts with piperazine to produce aminoethylpiperazine (6). The compounds EG, MEA, and EDA then further react to form diethanolamine (9), N-(2-hydroxyethyl) ethylenediamine (10), diethylenetriamine (11), and triethylenetetramine (12) Table 4 . Based on the performance evaluation results, the Co (0001) planes demonstrates lower catalytic activity, leading to fewer by-products that are challenging to analyze. On the p-Co-R with exposed (10−11) facets, after primary amines are formed from EG amination, the reaction more readily progresses towards carbon chain elongation, resulting in the production of C4 products and even C6 products. However, as the carbon chain lengthens, the aldehyde-amine condensation reaction becomes increasingly difficult. Conversely, c-Co-R with exposed (11−20) facets favors ring-forming reactions (5, 6, 7), producing piperazine, which further reacts with intermediates to form hydroxyethylpiperazine and aminoethylpiperazine. 4 Conclusion In summary, three Co-based catalysts with distinct crystal planes—p-Co-R, s-Co-R, and c-Co-R—were synthesized, each exposing the Co (10−11), Co (0001), and Co (11−20) planes, respectively. The Co (11−20) crystal planes exhibited higher EG conversion, as well as higher selectivity and yield, in comparison to the Co (10−11) and Co (0001) planes. Combining DFT calculations with experimental characterization, it is found that Co (11−20) planes exhibit a strong activation ability towards the C-H bond dissociation step in EG amination and a strong adsorption capacity towards EG, which will be conducive to the dehydrogenation of EG to aldehyde intermediates on the surface of Co and increase reaction conversion. Furthermore, weak adsorption of NH₃ on Co (11−20) can make it easier to hydrogenate imines to produce primary amines. These properties are the reasons for the high EG conversion and high selectivity of c-Co-R with exposed (11−20) facets. The crystal plane effect of Co-based catalysts affects the catalytic activity of EG amination by influencing the C-H bond breaking capacity, the adsorption capacity of EG and NH3. Overall, these results provide deeper insights into the crystal facet effects of Co-based catalysts in alcohol amination, paving the way for the rational design of excellent performance alcohol amination catalysts. coredata.dc:description: Co possesses outstanding dehydrogenation and hydrogenation activitiy and is a suitable catalyst for the amination of ethylene glycol. Nevertheless, the catalytic activity of Co's different crystal surfaces remains unclear, which hinders the further advancements in its catalytic efficiency. This research comprehensively examines the influence of Co's crystal plane effect on the amination of ethylene glycol employing both experimental and theoretical methodologies. Three single-crystal Co catalysts with mainly exposed (10−11), (0001) and (11−20) crystal planes were synthesized by a hydrothermal method and evaluated for ethylene glycol amination. The experimental results indicated that the c-Co-R catalyst with exposed Co (11–20) crystal facets exhibits optimal performance, with a 55.4 % ethylene glycol conversion and a 43.7 % primary amines (ethylenediamine and ethanolamine) selectivity. Combined with density-functional theory calculations and experimental characterization, the results showed that the Co (11−20) surface exhibited robust C-H bond dissociation and strong adsorption of ethylene glycol, which markedly improved the dehydrogenation efficiency of ethylene glycol and improved ethylene glycol conversion. Furthermore, the weak adsorption capacity of NH3 further promoted the selectivity of the target products.
